statement:
The continuous image of a compact set is also compact.

Let $X$ and $Y$ be topological spaces, $f \colon X \to Y$ be continuous,
$A$ be a compact subset of $X$, $I$ be an indexing set, and
$\{V_\alpha\}_{\alpha\in I}$ be an open cover of $f(A)$. Thus,
$\displaystyle f(A)\sub \bigcup_{\alpha\in I} V_\alpha$. Therefore,
$\displaystyle A\sub f^{-1}\bigg( f(A) \bigg) \sub f^{-1} \left( \bigcup_{\alpha\in I} V_{\alpha} \right)=\bigcup_{\alpha\in I} f^{-1} (V_\alpha)$.

Since $f$ is continuous, each $f^{-1}(V_\alpha)$ is an open subset of
$X$. Since $\displaystyle A\sub \bigcup_{\alpha\in I} f^{-1} (V_\alpha)$
and $A$ is compact, there exists $n \in \mathbb{N}$ with
$\displaystyle A\sub\bigcup_{j=1}^n f^{-1} \left( V_{\alpha_j} \right)$
for some $\alpha_1, \dots , \alpha_n \in I$. Hence,
$\displaystyle f(A)\sub f \left( \bigcup_{j=1}^n f^{-1} (V_{\alpha_j}) \right)=f\left( f^{-1} \left( \bigcup_{j=1}^n V_{\alpha_j} \right) \right) \sub \bigcup_{j=1}^n V_{\alpha_j}$.
It follows that $f(A)$ is compact.
names: continuous image of a compact set is compact
